title: Communications Services Down after Alphabet Earnings — Communications Services Roundup
text:
Communications services companies fell after disappointing earnings from Google parent Alphabet.

Shares of Alphabet fell after third-quarter earnings lagged some investors' expectations. "Bigger picture, [Alphabet's] third-quarter growth highlights the power of its robust innovation pipeline," said analysts at brokerage Morgan Stanley, in a research note. The Morgan Stanley analysts forecast billions of dollars of a new annual revenue stream in the coming years from a handful of services, including Maps and eCommerce.

T-Mobile-US attracted a higher number of premium cellphone subscribers in the third quarter than Verizon and AT&T combined even as the fate of its Sprint deal remained in limbo, as reported earlier. Facing investor pressure to justify its investment in content production, AT&T is preparing to unveil its answer to Netflix, a multibillion-dollar gamble that the media and telecom giant can sell a premium streaming-video service when rivals are flooding the market with cheaper alternatives.

AT&T is targeting an audience of 50 million subscribers within five years of the 2020 launch of a streaming service called HBO Max, which will air content from the cable channel, Warner Bros. movies and TV series such as "Friends." AT&T will enter the "streaming wars" raging between Netflix, Amazon.com's Prime and, soon, Walt Disney's Disney+.

Write to Rob Curran at rob.curran@dowjones.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

October 29, 2019 17:20 ET (21:20 GMT)
